awd_titl_txt: Trusting Strangers in the Sharing Economy
awd_abstract_narration:
SES-1257138
Paolo Parigi
Karen Cook
Stanford University

This project investigates whether individuals can be made more trusting of others through the use of technology. The investigators will recruit participants from on-line companies operating in the sharing economy, i.e., from websites where users share tools, hospitality, pet sitting, and car rides. The broad research hypothesis is that trusting strangers on-line makes individuals more trusting in general and that there are two key mechanisms for developing trust online: (1) the reputation systems that these websites develop to facilitate interactions, and (2) the individual social networks that create communities of users with similar levels of trust. The assumption on which this research rests is that trust can be engineered, i.e., that the amount of interpersonal trust we have toward others is not determined exclusively by cultural factors, societal norms or family upbringing.

The investigators will conduct behavioral experiments and collect data on the participants in the study. The experiments will capture whether repeated, on-line interactions with strangers produce behavioral changes in the lives of the participants. Participants will be randomly assigned to two conditions and followed over time. In one condition, they will be playing against a simulated agent that will pose as a generic user, while in the other condition they will play against a simulated agent that will pose as a website member. By measuring differences in how participants play these games in the two conditions we will be able to assess changes in the evolution of their levels of trust toward others. A portion of the subjects recruited for these experiments will come from outside the United States. The study will be conducted in two countries, Romania and the Netherlands, because they represent societies with low and high levels of generalized trust, respectively. This will enable cross-cultural comparisons and an examination whether the mechanisms identified operate similarly under different cultural conditions, particularly in high and low trust societies. In addition to the behavioral experiments, the researchers will also analyze a number of sharing economy web-based communities.
 
Broader Impact

The research contributes to the sparse scholarly research to date on the mechanisms used to build trust where trust might not otherwise emerge because of weak or corrupt institutions or the prevalence of conditions that are not conducive to fostering trustworthy behavior. In general, this is also a problem for Internet-mediated interactions that must be resolved to gain the confidence of those who use this medium for exchanges or other forms of interaction. Furthermore, understanding the fundamental nature of these processes will be beneficial not only to society but also to those mandated to protect individuals from fraud and harm, as well as to those who hope to benefit in various ways from the capacity to connect people from very different walks of life and cultures. Research findings will contribute to a better understanding of whether such networks foster greater cultural understanding or a variety of other positive aims.  Knowing how these types of network are formed, work, maintained and grow is very important for a well-functioning society, a growing economy, and effective governance.

por.por_cntn:
The project studies whether trust toward general others can be learned through induced behavior or technological interventions. We call this hypothesis the "engineering of trust" and our goal is to study people who are members of the sharing economy. The sharing economy is composed of companies and other organizations that allow their members to share services or goods often in return for a fee. Does participation in any of these activities change somebody's perceptions of trust in others? We also explored the impact that having a direct exchange as either a service provider or a consumer had on interpersonal trust and the impact that the accumulation of a reputation in the form of ratings had on trust.

We developed an online platform, The Exchange, which served as an online laboratory to study our main research question. The code developed for The Exchange has been made available to researchers, and teams in New Zealand and in The Netherlands are actively developing extensions. Our experimental platform aims to measure trust using a variation of the investment game. The investment game has been widely used by social psychologists and behavioral economists interested in having a measure of trust not based on survey data. The investment game is a variation of the prisoner's dilemma, which is a single­shot game in which participants decide how many of the endowed credits to invest in recipients, who in turn may cooperate or defect when deciding how many credits to return.

The first phase of development and testing resulted in a platform where 600 participants recruited primarily from two companies, HomeExchange.com and Rooster.com were asked to play the roles of investors and recipients. They also played a lottery game with the goal of measuring their risk attitudes. We divided participants into different cohorts and waves and collected multiple observations on how they responded to the behavioral games at different time points. We found that the frequency of activity predicts risk aversion, but only in interaction with satisfaction. These results were published in the journal Games.

In the second phase of our research, we signed a collaboration contract with Airbnb.com, a major company in the sharing economy whose aim is to enable trust to facilitate hospitality transactions. This version of our online laboratory allowed participants to play only one role, that of investor, and asked all of them to play a second time about three weeks after the first game.

We focused on the common tendency to trust others who are similar, known as homophily, and tested this argument using a randomized online experiment with 8,906 users of Airbnb. We generated synthetic profiles of the simulated recipients and presented them as other Airbnb users to participants who played the role of Investor. We then varied demographic and reputation features of the recipients in a structured way to study how these changes affected the amount of trust participants placed in the recipients as indicated by the amount they were willing to invest in them.

We established that homophily systematically structures most interactions. We then measured the extent to which the platform has the power to alter users' perceptions of trust through reputation mechanisms. We found that a positive reputation signal is enough to offset homophily. That is, a dissimilar other who exhibits a high reputation tends to be perceived as more trustworthy than a more similar counterpart with a lower reputation. We also present evidence that our experimental findings generalize to interaction dynamics in the real world through analyses of one million hospitality interactions on Airbnb. The paper reporting these results has been published in the Proceedings of National Academy of Sciences (PNAS), in August 2017.

We also published a methodological paper in the journal, Social Psychology Quarterly, that explores the experimental methodology we developed that we labelled "Online Field Experiments." Several other chapters related to our work have been published concerning more general issues of trust.

This project provided funding for the training of a Postdoctoral Fellow in our department. In addition, as part of this project, we hired an engineering master’s student at Stanford and trained him in social science methodology. This included, learning the basics of linear statistical models and of experimental analysis. In the spring quarter of 2016 we also had a visiting PhD student from Cornell Tech working on the data. We have also engaged other graduate students and RAs in our work on the sharing economy.

We presented our results at conferences nationally and internationally in the Social Sciences and in Computer Science, and presented invited talks at other research institutions. The results produced by our project were also presented in the main TED conference by Joe Gebbia, Airbnb’s co­founder. Additionally, a website has been developed to make our experimental data available to researchers interested in carrying out similar research in the future.
